title: How to Pack a Letterbox

steps.headline: Choose a spot to hide your box.
steps.description: The spot should be discreet and your box should not be visible or you run the risk of it being mistaken for trash or catch the eye of a curious vandal.

steps.headline: Find a watertight container large enough to hold a logbook and stamp.
steps.description: You may also want a box to include a pen, pencil, special ink-pads or even a "hitchhiker".

steps.headline: Put each letterbox item in a separate bag.
steps.description: You may want to double bag the journal/logbook. Quart size works well.

steps.headline: Make your own rubber stamp inspired by your hiding spot.
steps.description: A lousy hand carved stamp is better than a purchased stamp, but if you aren't an artist, consider purchasing a stamp that represents your hiding place well or have one custom made.

steps.headline: Unlined sketch pads are popular for letterbox logbook/journals.
steps.description: Or you can be creative and make a unique journal, index cards, cash register receipt scrolls or you can make a custom journal to fit your letterbox.

steps.headline: Wrap your stamp in felt, fabric or a small amount of paper towel before placing it in its bag, this protects other items from residual ink.
Label your box that it is a "Letterbox" and possibly with info about the hobby.
steps.description:
Do this in case someone accidentally finds your box and wants to learn more. An example label:
DO NOT REMOVE! -- DO NOT REMOVE! -- This is a letterbox -- “PEACE PILGRIM” -- Please sign our journal if you like, but replace everything just as you found it. -- For more info about this game: www.letterboxing.org / your email/ Letterbox Number.

steps.headline: Place the label inside a clear box so you can read it from the outside or insure the label won't wear off if placed on the outside.
steps.description: Try using nail polish or permanent marker.

text:
Choose a spot to hide your box. The spot should be discreet and your box should not be visible or you run the risk of it being mistaken for trash or catch the eye of a curious vandal. Find a watertight container large enough to hold a logbook and stamp. You may also want a box to include a pen, pencil, special ink-pads or even a "hitchhiker". Put each letterbox item in a separate bag. You may want to double bag the journal/logbook. Quart size works well. Make your own rubber stamp inspired by your hiding spot. A lousy hand carved stamp is better than a purchased stamp, but if you aren't an artist, consider purchasing a stamp that represents your hiding place well or have one custom made. Unlined sketch pads are popular for letterbox logbook/journals. Or you can be creative and make a unique journal, index cards, cash register receipt scrolls or you can make a custom journal to fit your letterbox. Wrap your stamp in felt, fabric or a small amount of paper towel before placing it in its bag, this protects other items from residual ink.  Label your box that it is a "Letterbox" and possibly with info about the hobby. Do this in case someone accidentally finds your box and wants to learn more. An example label:
DO NOT REMOVE! -- DO NOT REMOVE! -- This is a letterbox -- “PEACE PILGRIM” -- Please sign our journal if you like, but replace everything just as you found it. -- For more info about this game: www.letterboxing.org / your email/ Letterbox Number. Place the label inside a clear box so you can read it from the outside or insure the label won't wear off if placed on the outside. Try using nail polish or permanent marker.
